newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to sign accords with six C. American states.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to sign accords with six C. American states.

text.p: Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui plans to sign a series of accords with Central American nations to cement ties with the region, officials said on Wednesday.

"President Lee will sign memoranda on economic and trade cooperation with five Central American countries during his visit to Central America in September," economics minister Wang Chih-kang said on state television.
Wang identified the five countries as Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua -- all among the 30 states that recognise Taipei instead of Beijing.
Lee also will sign a free trade agreement with Panama, another Taipei ally.

Lee was expected to leave for Panama in early September, and would transit in Hawaii to and from Central America. The U.S. State Department has said it will issue a transit visa for Lee to pass through Honolulu on September 4-5 and September 17-18.
It would be Lee's first overseas visit since a 1995 U.S. trip that infuriated Beijing.

Beijing, which views Taiwan as a renegade province not entitled to international relations since they split after a civil was in 1949, has urged Washington not to allow Lee to pursue pro-independence activities while in Hawaii.

Wang, who recently returned from a Central American visit to prepare for Lee's September trip, said the signing of the accords with the six countries was a good basis to further promote Taiwan's ties with its diplomatic allies.

Analysts say Beijing has stepped up efforts to increase its influence in Latin America, the site of 16 Taiwan allies. With foreign exchange reserves of more than US$100 billion, China can assert a major influence in the region, they say.
China's trade with Latin America stood at US$730 million in 1978. By 1995 it had rocketed 730 percent to US$6.11 billion, Taiwan's China Times daily reported.
